title: If a>0 and a|b, then how do you prove or disprove that (a,b) = a? - Quora

response.answer_text: If a>0 and a|b, then how do you prove or disprove that (a,b) = a? To disprove something you just need a counterexample. To prove this you can use Euclid’s algorithm. Euclid showed that all divisors or [math]a[/math] and [math]b[/math] divide the remainder when [math]b[/math] is divided by [math]a[/math]. And conversely, all divisor of [math]a[/math] and the remainder divide [math]b[/math]. So you gain or lose no common divisors when you replace the greater of [math]a[/math] and [math]b[/math] by the remainder from dividing the greater by the smaller. So the process preserves the GCD. In your case you have already reached the last step of Euclid’s algorithm. The remainder is zero and the GCD must be the GCD of [math]a[/math] and zero. As every number divides zero, the GCD must be [math]a[/math]. Note Euclid had never heard of zero, he had to finish the argument differently.

For [math]n \in \mathbb Z[/math], let [math]{\mathcal D}(n)=\{d \in \mathbb Z: d \mid n\}[/math] denote the set of all divisors of [math]n[/math]. Note that [math]{\mathcal D}(n)[/math] is a finite set, except when [math]n=0[/math]. For [math]a,b \in \mathbb Z[/math], [math]a,b[/math] not both zero, [math]{\mathcal D}(a)\,\cap\,{\mathcal D}(b)[/math] is a finite set, and [math]\gcd(a,b) = \max \left({\mathcal D}(a)\,\cap\,{\mathcal D}(b) \right)[/math]. Since [math]a \in {\mathcal D}(a)\,\cap\,{\mathcal D}(b)[/math] and since no [math]n>a[/math] can belong to [math]{\mathcal D}(a)[/math], and hence also not to [math]{\mathcal D}(a)\,\cap\,{\mathcal D}(b)[/math], we must have [math]\gcd(a,b) = \max \left({\mathcal D}(a)\,\cap\,{\mathcal D}(b) \right) = a. \blacksquare[/math]
